So, what we did here was to wonder,

that deorbitals changed everything.
And it's true, so why transition metals
have been so, so good at doing catalysis over the years?
And one of the answers that we came up with
is their ability to basically revolve
between different oxidation states
when they are doing catalysis.
So we asked a very simple and fundamental question,
which is could we take those properties
that have been doing transition metals extremely powerful,
and bring them over to an element
that is not in the D block, but is into the P block?
And we looked in particular to these elements here,
bismuth, because it attracted my attention.
Certain features attracted my attention, certainly.

like iridium, platinum, gold, which makes it very cheap,

to try to unlock the redox properties of bismuth,
of the main group element.
So our approach was divided into two different manifolds,
the low-valent catalysis with bismuth,
and the high-valent catalysis.
So the low-valent would take a low-valent bismuth I,
and would revolve all the way up to bismuth III,
and back to bismuth I in this way,
whereas the high-valent catalysis
would start from a bismuth III complex,
go all the way to bismuth V, and back to bismuth III
in the catalytic cycle.

a little bit, in this front, in both fronts,
and I just don't have time to mention,
to cover all the projects that we developed here,
